entry.title: Neetings, my meeting notes app is now open source! ü§ñ

link.title: Neetings, my meeting notes app is now open source! ü§ñ

entry.content:
I wanted to open source it one day,
and that day is today! üéâ
(I finally found the courage to simply put it out there.)

neetings is a meeting notes app I built over the last few months to solve my own pain points with chaotic meeting notes. It uses smart block types and Kanban-style organization to turn messy notes into actionable content.

Everybody and their dog was/is/loves/hates vibe-coding these days.
I wanted to know what the fuss was about. And, boy, do I know now.

The feeling is bittersweet: I‚Äôm excited to share the project and see if others find it useful ‚Äî the product likely wouldn‚Äôt exist without AI assistance. At the same time, I can‚Äôt maintain it alone without additional help or more AI.

Because it‚Äôs 99% AI-generated (mostly Claude Code), I don‚Äôt feel confident supporting it long-term. Maybe someone else will find it useful or build on it ‚Äî let‚Äôs do it together! Together, we might truly own the software someday. ü§û

Being React-based, it should be fairly straightforward to adapt or extend.

Of course, there are still some improvements I want to make, like:

  • ‚Äú@mentions‚Äù for attendees
  • a few more keyboard shortcuts

For now, I‚Äôm happy to share the code with you all.
Time to move on to new things. üöÄ

You stay classy San Diego.
‚Äî Ron Burgundy

entry.title: Are you missing yazi to show file sizes and dates?

link.title: Are you missing yazi to show file sizes and dates?

entry.content:
Then you’re lucky, because linemode is what you need see the docs

You can also specify any 1 to 20 characters, and extend it within a UI plugin, which means you can implement your own linemode through the plugin system like this:

# ~/.config/yazi/yazi.toml
[mgr]
linemode = "size_and_mtime"

Then in your init:

-- ~/.config/yazi/init.lua
function Linemode:size_and_mtime()
	local time = math.floor(self._file.cha.mtime or 0)
	if time == 0 then
		time = ""
	elseif os.date("%Y", time) == os.date("%Y") then
		time = os.date("%b %d %H:%M", time)
	else
		time = os.date("%b %d  %Y", time)
	end

	local size = self._file:size()
	return string.format("%s %s", size and ya.readable_size(size) or "-", time)
end

entry.title: Open Source Isn‚Äôt Free‚ÄîIt‚Äôs a Gift. Treat It Like One.

link.title: Open Source Isn‚Äôt Free‚ÄîIt‚Äôs a Gift. Treat It Like One.

entry.content:
TL;DR

  • Give back‚Äîwith money (even $1 helps), time, or skills.
  • Limit corporate influence. If we fund projects, coporate control is limited.
  • Your donation isn‚Äôt just cash‚Äîit‚Äôs proof that someone cares.
  • Pick one project you rely on and set up a donation today.

Table of Contents

  • Why am I writing this post?
  • Why this matters for all of us
  • How to give back (without overthinking it)
    • 1. Money (the fastest way to say ‚ÄúThank You‚Äù)
    • 2. Time or skills (if money‚Äôs tight)
    • 3. Spread the word
  • The ripple effect
  • My ask
  • A personal note

Why am I writing this post?

Christmas is that rare time when we pause‚Äîwhen the year‚Äôs chaos slows just enough to reflect, celebrate, or reset. For many of us, it‚Äôs also when we realize how much we owe to things we take for granted.

Like open-source software.

Think about the tools you use daily: the Linux server hosting your favorite site, the tiny npm package that saved you hours, the text editor that‚Äôs become an extension of your thoughts. Someone wrote that. Someone maintains it. And most of them do it for free.

I‚Äôve been on both sides of this. I‚Äôve used free software without a second thought, and I‚Äôve stayed up late fixing bugs in projects no one pays me for. Here‚Äôs the truth: Open source isn‚Äôt free. It‚Äôs a gift. And gifts deserve gratitude.

For some odd reason I don‚Äôt quite remember, I read this GitHub discussion (PrawnPDF), and it sparked a snowball of thoughts over the past few weeks.

Why this matters for all of us

We developers are lucky. Despite the noise about AI replacing us or ‚Äú10x engineers‚Äù hogging the spotlight, we‚Äôre still needed. Hell, we‚Äôre needed more than ever‚Äîbecause the world runs on people, either writing code or overseeing the systems that do.

Here are some heavyweights we all have heard of:

  • The Linux and BSD kernels powering your internet.
  • The web servers and proxies serving your data.
  • The email client (like Thunderbird) you rely on.

These things don‚Äôt materialize out of thin air. They‚Äôre built by people who could be doing paid work instead. They‚Äôre acts of generosity.

How to give back (without overthinking it)

You don‚Äôt need to be rich or a corporate sponsor. You just need to pick one project and act.

1. Money (the fastest way to say ‚ÄúThank You‚Äù)

Most of us can spare $5 or $10. That‚Äôs not much to you, but to a maintainer, it‚Äôs:

  • A cup of coffee to fuel an after-work debug session.
  • The slice of pizza that sparks joy.
  • Proof that someone notices their work.
  • Motivation to keep going, even when it feels pointless.

Where to start?

  • GitHub Sponsors (one-time or recurring).
  • Open Collective (for teams/projects).
  • A project‚Äôs Patreon or PayPal (check their README).

Are you lazy? Set up a yearly donation now‚Äîfuture you won‚Äôt even miss it.

2. Time or skills (if money‚Äôs tight)

  • Get in touch. Offer help.
  • Fix a bug. Even a typo in the docs helps.
  • Answer questions in forums or GitHub issues.
  • Write a thank-you email. Seriously. Maintainers remember those.

3. Spread the word

  • Star the repo. Tweet about it. Tell a friend.
  • Visibility = sustainability.

The ripple effect

Here‚Äôs what happens when you donate:

  1. A maintainer sees your name and thinks, ‚ÄúSomeone gives a damn.‚Äù
  2. They fix one more bug, write one more test, or‚Äîjust as important‚Äîdon‚Äôt lose their spark of joy.
  3. The project stays alive. Your tools stay free. The cycle continues.

This isn‚Äôt charity. It‚Äôs mutualism.
You‚Äôre not just giving back‚Äîyou‚Äôre investing in the infrastructure of your own work.

My ask

This holiday, pick one project you rely on and give something back. Not next year. Not when you‚Äôre ‚Äúless busy.‚Äù Now.

I donated to:

  • kitty (my daily terminal emulator).
  • Let‚Äôs Encrypt (because without it, I wouldn‚Äôt host anything).

What‚Äôs yours?

A personal note

This year was a big one for me: I switched mostly from macOS to give Bazzite and Fedora a shot. It turned out to be a huge success and introduced me to a ton of new, free software I now rely on:

  • fish shell
  • distrobox
  • Homebrew (omnipresent on Linux‚Äîdonations welcome)
  • Neovim + LazyVim
  • (And a bunch of others we‚Äôre collecting on shell-curry)

I‚Äôll be donating to more of these over the next year. Of course, Pi-hole gets its annual tip! And OpenFreeMap, I love you.

Open source gave you a gift. Treat it like one.

entry.title: Distrobox exported app no sound output

link.title: Distrobox exported app no sound output

entry.content:
You‚Äôre an avid Distrobox user, but after exporting your favourite browser, there no sound üòø

You need to support Pulse Audio!

Pavucontrol is the gold-standard for managing the Pulse Audio sound server on Linux. Despite this, it‚Äôs not the default sound manager tool on mainstream Linux distributions. As a result, before we can continue with this tutorial, we‚Äôll need to go over how to install the Pavucontrol audio manager.

To install Pavucontrol, launch a terminal window and follow the instructions that correspond with your Linux operating system.

I will use Debian for demonstration, so you‚Äôll find your package - I am sure!

Install the GTK version:

sudo apt-get install pavucontrol

And for QT install:

sudo apt-get install pavucontrol-qt

After installing Mariah Carey was blasting out loud on the speakers.

entry.title: Speed up Vulkan Shader Compilation on Bazzite

link.title: Speed up Vulkan Shader Compilation on Bazzite

entry.content:
Steam can take ages to precompile the shaders for Vulkan?

Hard to find, easy to implement:

nvim .local/share/Steam/steam_dev.cfg

and edit/add those two lines:

@ShaderBackgroundProcessingThreads 8
unShaderBackgroundProcessingThreads 8

Make sure to adjust, the 8 is fine in my case. The number represents the numbers of CPU cores Vulkan can use.

entry.title: ssh: Copying, Pasting - not working with Wayland

link.title: ssh: Copying, Pasting - not working with Wayland

entry.content:
You‚Äôre tugging along happily, setting things up, but one thing starts bothering you.

Let‚Äôs say, you have a config file open in (n)vim on your server and want to select parts and paste them somewhere else.

Ctrl+Shift+C and Ctrl+Shift+V are not working from inside (n)vim editors ü§î

You resort to the solution, that always slipped your mind in the past:

Visually selecting the parts in vim and yanking to clipboard with "+y - well, that‚Äôs broken, too.

vim system register * and + not working

Neovim should work.
But, it does not.

Googling brought me to: sudo apt install wl-clipboard.

You need a modern Neovim (> 0.10.x) build with Wayland clipboard support!

This works because Wayland uses a different clipboard protocol than X11. The wl-clipboard package provides the necessary tools (wl-copy and wl-paste) that Neovim uses to interface with Wayland‚Äôs clipboard, enabling the + and * registers to function properly.

Some things are just plain hard in Linux.

For copy-pasting with vim

https://stackoverflow.com/a/61379319

Assuming you only want to copy line sections of the file, do shift+v to go into visual mode and only highlight the lines I want to copy. Then do.

:'<,'>w !wl-copy

where

'<,'> - means you used visual mode to select a range (you don‚Äôt type this) w !{cmd} - write the range to the stdin of cmd, see more at :help w_c

entry.title: Setting Up Nerd Fonts for Kitty and LazyVim on Bazzite

link.title: Setting Up Nerd Fonts for Kitty and LazyVim on Bazzite

entry.content:
If you‚Äôre new to Linux and just getting started, this guide is for you.

My setup:

  • OS: Bazzite (Gnome)
  • Terminal Emulator: Kitty
  • Editor: LazyVim (inside a distrobox)

After setting up your distrobox with your preferred tools (likely what you were comfortable with before switching to an atomic distribution), it‚Äôs time to get coding.

You install packages via brew, apt, dnf, or pacman, finally open LazyVim, and‚Ä¶ the icons are missing. Damn.

Here‚Äôs the fix:

Download your favorite font from nerdfonts.com and unzip it.

Copy or move the *.ttf files into ~/.local/share/fonts/:

cp *.ttf ~/.local/share/fonts/

Close all distroboxes and Kitty windows, then open a fresh Kitty terminal and run:

kitten choose-fonts

Pick your favorite font ü•≥
Enjoy!

entry.title: Type emojis in LazyVim (in a Kitty terminal)

link.title: Type emojis in LazyVim (in a Kitty terminal)

entry.content:
As I‚Äôm learning LazyVim, I ran into a surprisingly tricky problem: how do I type emojis from my keyboard? Here‚Äôs how I solved it.

My Setup

  • OS: Bazzite (Gnome)
  • Terminal Emulator: Kitty

The Problem

When you‚Äôre trying to stay keyboard-focused in LazyVim, reaching for the mouse to insert an emoji feels wrong. Gnome has a built-in emoji picker (accessible via mouse), but there has to be a better way.

Solution #1: External Emoji Picker

I use smile (the Flatpak version) combined with switcher to quickly launch an emoji picker and paste the selection. This works, but it still requires switching windows.

Solution #2: Kitty‚Äôs Built-in Unicode Input

Kitty has a fantastic built-in Unicode input kitten that lets you search and insert emojis directly from your keyboard. When triggered, it opens a searchable interface right in your terminal.

According to the docs, ctrl+shift+u should activate it. Unfortunately, this keybinding didn‚Äôt work for me‚Äîlikely conflicting with LazyVim or Gnome keybindings.

The Fix: Remap the Keybinding

Edit your ~/.config/kitty/kitty.conf and add a custom keybinding:

#: Unicode input

# Default keybindings (commented out if they don't work)
# map kitty_mod+u    kitten unicode_input
# map ctrl+cmd+space kitten unicode_input

# Custom keybinding - use something that doesn't conflict
map ctrl+alt+u kitten unicode_input

Note: I initially tried ctrl+u, but that conflicts with Vim‚Äôs ‚Äúscroll up half page‚Äù command. ctrl+alt+u is a safer choice that won‚Äôt interfere with your editing workflow.

How to Use It

  1. Press your mapped keybinding (e.g., ctrl+alt+u)
  2. A searchable emoji picker appears in your terminal
  3. Type to search (e.g., ‚Äúsmile‚Äù, ‚Äúrocket‚Äù, ‚Äúfire‚Äù)
  4. Use arrow keys to navigate, press Enter to insert

Now go on and smash that üòº

entry.title: Code Clojure in NeoVim (with LazyVim and Conjure)

link.title: Code Clojure in NeoVim (with LazyVim and Conjure)

entry.content:
Want to develop Clojure with a modern, interactive REPL experience right in NeoVim? This guide will walk you through setting up Conjure with LazyVim for a smooth Clojure development workflow.

Prerequisites

Before we begin, make sure you have the following installed:

  1. Java - A modern Java version (I recommend Temurin 23)
  2. Clojure - Get it from clojure.org
  3. LazyVim - If you haven‚Äôt set this up yet, check out LazyVim‚Äôs installation guide

Configure nREPL

First, configure nREPL in your project. Add this to your ~/.clojure/deps.edn file to make nREPL available globally:

{:aliases
 {:nREPL
  {:extra-deps {nrepl/nrepl {:mvn/version "1.4.0"}}}}}

Version 1.4.0 is the latest stable release at the time of writing.

For more configuration options, check the nREPL documentation.

Configure LazyVim

LazyVim makes this super easy! Simply enable the Clojure/Conjure extras:

  1. Open LazyVim and run :LazyExtras
  2. Search for and enable the lang.clojure extra
  3. Restart NeoVim to apply the changes

This will automatically install Conjure and configure it for Clojure development.

Start Coding

Now you‚Äôre ready to code! Here‚Äôs the workflow:

1. Start the nREPL Server

In a separate terminal at your project root, start the nREPL server:

clj -M:nREPL -m nrepl.cmdline

You should see output showing the server started on a specific port (but you don‚Äôt need to worry about it).

2. Open Your Project in NeoVim

nvim .

When you open a .clj file, Conjure will automatically detect and connect to your running nREPL server.

3. Learn Conjure‚Äôs Keybindings

Conjure comes with an interactive tutorial! Run this command in NeoVim:

:ConjureSchool

This will teach you all the essential keybindings for evaluating code, managing the REPL, and more.

Quick Tips

  • Evaluate current form: Place your cursor inside a form and use <localleader>ee
  • Evaluate file: <localleader>ef to evaluate the entire file
  • View documentation: K while hovering over a function
  • Open REPL log: <localleader>ls to see evaluation results

Happy Clojure coding! üéâ
